element.name: TSpecDesc
element.short: Helper class to set Image descriptors.
element.descr: Image Descriptors can be set in different ways, mostly as string but also as Integer constant. This class helps with setting up this.

element.name: TBubble
element.short: Black box structure for a Bubble help

element.name: PBubble
element.short: Handle for a Bubble Help

element.name: TBubbleList
element.short: Type to keep a list of open Bubbles to close them after application is terminated
element.descr: The Bubbles are not automatically destroyed by MUI. Therefore we destroy them on the end of Application.

element.name: TMUIRGB
element.short: Type for a typical MUI RGB Color with three LongWords to describe the color.
element.descr: Attention: a white color will be $ffffffff, $ffffffff, $ffffffff (in contrast a $ff, $ff, $ff would be still black)

element.name: TMUIRGB.Red
element.short: Red color part in 32 bit (0..$ffffffff)

element.name: TMUIRGB.Green
element.short: Green color part in 32 bit (0..$ffffffff)

element.name: TMUIRGB.Blue
element.short: Blue color part in 32 bit (0..$ffffffff)

element.name: PMUIRGB
element.short: Pointer to a list of MUI RGB color with three LongWords for every color

element.name: TMUIArea
element.short: Super class for every other MUI class except windows and applications

descr.p: Area class is a super class for every other MUI class except windows and applications. It holds information about an objects current position, size and weight and manages frames, fonts and backgrounds.

Additionally, area class handles the user input. By setting an objects MUIA_InputMode, you can make it behave like a button or like a toggle gadget. That's why MUI doesn't offer an extra button class. A button is simply a text object with a raised frame and a relverify input mode. Since especially group class is a subclass of area, you can create rather complex buttons consisting of many other display elements.

element.name: TMUIArea.AfterCreateObject
element.short: Started after the MUI Object is created to connect events.
element.descr: Will be called by CreateObject there is no reason to call it yourself.

element.name: TMUIArea.BeforeCloseWindow
element.short: Called before the window gets closed or the application get terminated to clean some contents

element.name: TMUIArea.GetCreateTags
element.short: Get the properties of this class as TagList to create the MUI Object
element.descr: Will be called by CreateObject there is no reason to call it yourself.

element.name: TMUIArea.GetCreateTags.ATagList
element.short: TagList to add the properties for this class.

element.name: TMUIArea.FillArea
element.short: Prevent MUI of drawing the background (Init only)
element.descr: Set this to False if you are a custom class and dont want area class to clear your background during the DoSuperMethod() in your draw method. Note that if you set this, your draw method is responsible for filling every pixel of your objects rectangle, otherwise some display trash will remain there.

element.name: TMUIArea.Create
element.short: Create the class and init the properties

element.name: TMUIArea.Destroy
element.short: Destroy the class, if the MUI object is still alive it will be disconnected and destroyed as well.

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateObject
element.short: Create the MUI object.
element.descr: This will be called by the Parent class, usually you do not need to call this yourself.

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateBubble
element.short: Create a MUI Bubble

descr.p: Together with DeleteBubble(), this method provides an interface for MUIs bubble mechanism. Applications can use bubbles for their own purpose, e.g. for indicating error conditions on certain gadgets.

CreateBubble() creates a bubble at the specified coordinates with the specified (textual) contents. It returns a bubble "handle" that has to be passed to DeleteBubble() when the bubble shall disappear.

There's no limitation on the number of bubbles, you can create lots of them at a time if you wish. Also, these custom bubbles are completely independant of MUI's bubble help system and won't disappear automatically when the mouse is moved.

Note that bubbles will only show up when the object in question is visible. Otherwise CreateBubble() returns nil. You are responsible for deleting the bubble before the object get's invisible. Good place to remove a custom bubble is e.g. the Hide method of your object.
Defined flags:

dl.dd: prevents MUI from hiding the mouse pointer when displaying the help bubble. It is recommended that you always set this, unless your bubble is meant to disappear as soon as there is some user input.

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateBubble.Result
element.short: Bubble Handle use to close the bubble again with: DeleteBubble()

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateBubble.x
element.short: window related x position to open the bubble

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateBubble.y
element.short: window related y position to open the bubble

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateBubble.Txt
element.short: Text to show inside the bubble

element.name: TMUIArea.CreateBubble.Flags
element.short: Flags for the bubble, see table

element.name: TMUIArea.DeleteBubble
element.short: Deletes a previously created Bubble

descr.p: Together with CreateBubble(), this method provides an interface for MUIs bubble mechanism. Applications can use bubbles for their own purpose, e.g. for indicating error conditions on certain gadgets.
DeleteBubble deletes a bubble that was previously created with CreateBubble(). Note that bubbles have to be deleted before an object get's invisible!

element.name: TMUIArea.DeleteBubble.Bubble
element.short: Bubble handle returned by CreateBubble()

element.name: TMUIArea.DeleteAllBubbles
element.short: Delete all bubbles which are created with CreateBubble() for this object
element.descr: The object remembers the open bubbles, with this method you can call all bubbles opened on this object. Note: all the bubble handles become invalid in this moment.

element.name: TMUIArea.LeftEdge
element.short: Current left position of the object

descr.p: You can use this to read the current position and dimension of an object, if you e.g. need it to pop up some requester below.
Of course, this attribute is only valid when the parent window of the object is currently open.

element.name: TMUIArea.TopEdge
element.short: Current top position of the object

descr.p: You can use this to read the current position and dimension of an object, if you e.g. need it to pop up some requester below.
Of course, this attribute is only valid when the parent window of the object is currently open.

element.name: TMUIArea.RightEdge
element.short: Current Right edge of the object

descr.p: You can use this to read the current position and dimension of an object, if you e.g. need it to pop up some requester below.
Of course, this attribute is only valid when the parent window of the object is currently open.

element.name: TMUIArea.BottomEdge
element.short: Current bottom edge of the object

descr.p: You can use this to read the current position and dimension of an object, if you e.g. need it to pop up some requester below.
Of course, this attribute is only valid when the parent window of the object is currently open.

element.name: TMUIArea.Height
element.short: Current Height of the object

descr.p: You can use this to read the current position and dimension of an object, if you e.g. need it to pop up some requester below.
Of course, this attribute is only valid when the parent window of the object is currently open.

element.name: TMUIArea.Width
element.short: Current Width of the object

descr.p: You can use this to read the current position and dimension of an object, if you e.g. need it to pop up some requester below.
Of course, this attribute is only valid when the parent window of the object is currently open.

element.name: TMUIArea.Pressed
element.short: Mouse press state of the object

descr.p: The Pressed attribute of a gadget is triggered by some user action, depending on the input mode:

ul.li: cleared when lmb is released and the mouse is still over the gadget (otherwise it will be cleared too, but without triggering a notification event).

dl.dd: undefined, use Selected for this.
undefined, use Selected for this.

element.name: TMUIArea.Window
element.short: Pointer to the Intution structure PWindow

descr.p: This attribute can be used to get a pointer to the intuition window structure of the parent window ot the object. This pointer could e.g. be used in calls to asl.library.
The result is only valid when the window is opened.

element.name: TMUIArea.WindowObject
element.short: Get the Window object the object is placed in
element.descr: You can obtain a pointer to the window object that some gadget belongs to by using this attribute. Useful mainly within Events if you do not want to deal with global variables.

element.name: TMUIArea.Background
element.short: [i] Adjust the background for an object.

descr.p: Every MUI object has its own background setting. The background is displayed "behind" the actual object contents, e.g. behind a the text of a text object or behind the image of an image object.
This attribute takes the same values as MUIA_Image_Spec, please refer to autodocs of image class for a complete description.

An object without a specific background setting will inherit the pattern from its parent group. The default background for a window and many other background patterns are adjustable with the preferences program.
Only a few MUII_* tags make sense as background.
Important are:

dl.dd: You have to set this when you create a button gadget. Thus, your button will be displayed in the users preferred style.
Set this when you create a text object with a TextFrame, e.g. some kind of status line. Do *not* use MUII_TextBack for simple text without frame (e.g. gadget labels).
dl.dt: MUII_BACKGROUND, MUII_SHADOW, MUII_SHINE, MUII_FILL, MUII_SHADOWBACK, MUII_SHADOWFILL, MUII_SHADOWSHINE, MUII_FILLBACK, MUII_FILLSHINE, MUII_SHINEBACK, MUII_SHINEBACK2
dl.dd: One of MUI's predefined pattern. These are not configurable by the user and will always look the same.

element.name: TMUIArea.ControlChar
element.short: Define a shortcut for the object

descr.p: Pressing the control char will have the same effect as pressing return if the object was active.
This can be used to create old style key shortcuts.
Note: Using an uppercase control char will force the user to press shift.

element.name: TMUIArea.CycleChain
element.short: Add the item to cycle chain
element.descr: Set to one to add the object to the cycle chain. (can navigate with TAB through the items in the chain)

element.name: TMUIArea.Disabled
element.short: Disable the item for user input and grey it out

descr.p: Disable or enable a gadget. Setting this attribute causes a gadget to become disabled, it gets a ghost pattern and doesn't respond to user input any longer.
Disabled gadgets cannot be activated with the TAB key.
Using Disable on a group of objects will disable all objects within that group.

element.name: TMUIArea.Draggable
element.short: Enable Drag'n'Drop for this object.
element.descr: Set this if you want the complete object to be dragable for Drag'n'Drop operations.

element.name: TMUIArea.Dropable
element.short: Make the item as a drop destination
element.descr: Only objects with this attribute set to True will be asked if they want to become an active Drag'n'Drop destination at all. Though this attribute defaults to True, this doesn't mean that every object automatically acepts Drag'nDrop actions, because the DragQuery method is answered False when it arrives at area class.

element.name: TMUIArea.FixHeight
element.short: [i] Give your object a fixed pixel height.
element.descr: This property is absolutely not needed in a general MUI application and only present for emergency situations. Please think twice before using it!

element.name: TMUIArea.FixHeightTxt
element.short: [i] Give your object a fixed pixel height. Defined by a text height
element.descr: The height will match the height of the given string. This property is absolutely not needed in a general MUI application and only present for emergency situations. Please think twice before using it!

element.name: TMUIArea.FixWidth
element.short: [i] Give your object a fixed pixel width.
element.descr: This property is absolutely not needed in a general MUI application and only present for emergency situations. Please think twice before using it!

element.name: TMUIArea.FixWidthTxt
element.short: [i] Give your object a fixed pixel width. Defined by a text width
element.descr: The Width will match the width of the given string. This property is absolutely not needed in a general MUI application and only present for emergency situations. Please think twice before using it!

element.name: TMUIArea.Font
element.short: [i] Define the Font for the item

descr.p: Every MUI object can have its own font, just set it with this tag. Objects without an explicit font setting will inherit it from their parent group.
You normally won't need to open a font yourself, just use one of the predefined values to get a font from the users preferences.
Special Inputs:

p.b: MUIV_Font_Inherit, MUIV_Font_Normal, MUIV_Font_List, MUIV_Font_Tiny, MUIV_Font_Fixed, MUIV_Font_Title, MUIV_Font_Big, MUIV_Font_Button, MUIV_Font_Slider, MUIV_Font_Gauge

element.name: TMUIArea.Frame
element.short: [i] Define a frame for the item.

descr.p: Since area class is a superclass for all elements in a window, you can assign frames to every object you wish.
You don't adjust the style of your frame directly, instead you only specify a type:

dl.dd: for standard buttons with text in it.
for small buttons with images, e.g. the arrows of a scrollbar.
for a text field, e.g. a status line display.
for a string gadget.
for a read only list.
for a list that handles input (has a cursor).
for proportional gadgets.
for groups.

descr.p: How the frame is going to look is adjustable via the preferences program.

Four spacing values belong to each frame that tell MUI how many pixels should be left free between the frame and its contents. These spacing values are also user adjustable as long as you don't override them with one of InnerLeft, InnerRight, InnerTop or InnerBottom.

element.name: TMUIArea.FramePhantomHoriz
element.short: [i] Hide the horizontal frame part

descr.p: Setting this to True causes the specified frame to be a horizontal phantom frame. The frame will not appear but its vertical components (frame height, inner top and inner bottom spacing) will be used to calculate positions and dimensions (horizontal components are treated as 0).

This is extremely useful for a correct labeling of objects. You would e.g. label a string gadget by using a text object with a phantom string frame. Thus, the label text will be always on the same vertical position as the string gadget text, no matter what spacing values the user configured.

element.name: TMUIArea.FrameTitle
element.short: Define a frame title text

descr.p: This tag identifies a text string that will be displayed centered in the top line of a frame. This can become handy if you want to name groups of objects.
You may not use FrameTitle without defining a Frame.

element.name: TMUIArea.HorizDisappear
element.short: Set horizontal disappear level

descr.p: Objects with a disappear level disappear automatically when their parent window gets too small to display them. Use this for things that make your GUI look nicer (e.g. Imagery) but are not absolutely necessary.
By using disappearing objects, you can make nice GUIs which still work on crappy 640x200 screens.
You can give horizontal or vertical disappear levels to objects which are used for horizontal or vertical layout calculations respectively.
Objects with a small disappear level disappear before objects with a big disappear level.

element.name: TMUIArea.VertDisappear
element.short: Set vertical disappear level

descr.p: Objects with a disappear level disappear automatically when their parent window gets too small to display them. Use this for things that make your GUI look nicer (e.g. Imagery) but are not absolutely necessary.
By using disappearing objects, you can make nice GUIs which still work on crappy 640x200 screens.
You can give horizontal or vertical disappear levels to objects which are used for horizontal or vertical layout calculations respectively.
Objects with a small disappear level disappear before objects with a big disappear level.

element.name: TMUIArea.HorizWeight
element.short: Adjust the horizontal weight of an object.
element.descr: Usually you can simply use Weight instead of this tag but in some two-dimensional groups it may become handy to have different horizontal and vertical weights.

element.name: TMUIArea.VertWeight
element.short: Adjust the vertical weight of an object.
element.descr: Usually you can simply use Weight instead of this tag but in some two-dimensional groups it may become handy to have different horizontal and vertical weights.

element.name: TMUIArea.InnerLeft
element.short: [i] Adjust the space between an object and its frame.
element.descr: Usually you shouldn't use this tag since you will override the users preferred default setting.

element.name: TMUIArea.InnerTop
element.short: [i] Adjust the space between an object and its frame.
element.descr: Usually you shouldn't use this tag since you will override the users preferred default setting.

element.name: TMUIArea.InnerRight
element.short: [i] Adjust the space between an object and its frame.
element.descr: Usually you shouldn't use this tag since you will override the users preferred default setting.

element.name: TMUIArea.InnerBottom
element.short: [i] Adjust the space between an object and its frame.
element.descr: Usually you shouldn't use this tag since you will override the users preferred default setting.

element.name: TMUIArea.InputMode
element.short: [i] Defines how the item react to user input

descr.p: efinition of reaction to user input:

dl.dd: No input, this is not a gadget.
Item pressed down as long the mouse is pressed, up when Mouse is realeased. For buttons and similar stuff.
Item changed the selection status to selected when clicked. Used e.g. in a radio button object.
Item toggles its selection status when clicked. For things like checkmark gadgets.

element.name: TMUIArea.MaxHeight
element.short: [i] Specify a maximum height for an object (in pixels).

element.name: TMUIArea.MaxWidth
element.short: [i] Specify a maximum width for an object (in pixels).

element.name: TMUIArea.Selected
element.short: Get and set the selected state of a gadget.

descr.p: This attribute can be triggered by the user clicking on the gadget (or using the keyboard), depending on the input mode:

ul.li: cleared when the gadget is selected and the mouse leaves the gadget box.
set when the mouse reenters the gadget box.

dl.dd: Item pressed down as long the mouse is pressed, up when Mouse is realeased. For buttons and similar stuff.
Item changed the selection status to selected when clicked. Used e.g. in a radio button object.
Item toggles its selection status when clicked. For things like checkmark gadgets.

element.name: TMUIArea.ShortHelp
element.short: Specify a string that is to be used as bubble help for this object.

element.name: TMUIArea.ShowSelState
element.short: [i] Invert the Frame border when item is selected
element.descr: Normally a gadget will reverse its frame and display the configured MUII_SelectedBack background pattern in its selected state. For some objects (e.g. checkmarks) this is not recommended and can be supressed by setting ShowSelState to False.

element.name: TMUIArea.Weight
element.short: The weight of an object determines how much room it will get during the layout process.

descr.p: This tag is a shorthand for HorizWeight and VertWeight, it sets both weights at once.

Imagine you have a 100 pixel wide horizontal group with two string gadgets. Usually, each gadget will get half of the room and be 50 pixels wide. If you feel the left gadget is more important and should be bigger, you can give it a weight of 200 (and 100 for the right gadget). Because the left gadget is twice as "heavy" as the right gadget, it will become twice as big (about 66 pixel) as the right one (34 pixel).
Of course giving weights only makes sense if the object is resizable. A VertWeight for a (always fixed height) string gadget is useless.
An object with a weight of 0 will always stay at its minimum size.
By default, all objects have a weight of 100.

element.name: TMUIArea.OnClick
element.short: Event when Item is clicked and in InputMode = MUIV_InputMode_RelVerify

descr.p: Mainly use for Buttons to check when the Button is clicked. The event reacts on the release of Pressed
